Transcription for 774121

Thank you Foo for agreeing to this interview, Denise. My name is Ewan and this is Bernard.
So when were you born? I was born on the 4th of January 1968. And Foo, what's that? In Exeter.
So I moved up here on my second birthday. So we moved into Goldfinch Coast on the 4th of January
1970. And we moved up because my father was a mechanic working for somebody in Exeter,
but he had the opportunity to come up with his business partner at the time, Tony Rake Straw,
and they came up together to run the Palmeric Service Station. And Tony ran the petrol side
of it and the shop with his wife Margaret, and my dad ran the mechanic side of it.
And that's what brought us up here on my birthday. I was two.
So obviously taking them into consideration that you were two,
what did you think of the area when you first arrived?
When I was little, I can't remember anything obviously from moving up, I can't remember when
I was two, but my very early days in this street, I remember playing out on that green
and with lots of children, lots of other children in the street.
So there are two greens in Goldfinch, there's one directly outside my house and there's one
a little bit further up. And the children from further up the road used to play on that green
and we used to play on this green. Occasionally we would get together. But my earliest memories
are of playing hide and seek and games like that and skipping and two balls and various things
like that out in the green and my mum calling me in because it was tea time and time to come in.
So obviously it's very different from Exeter.
Yes, we used to go down to Exeter a few times a year because all of my family were down there.
So my my gran, my auntie's, uncle's, cousins, everybody was down in Exeter and it was only
my close family that were up here. So I don't remember Exeter obviously from when I lived there
but I do remember those visits down to my gran and to visit my cousins and that.
Exeter is just a very busy city with lots of cars, lots of people but my memories of Exeter
really are going down to visit my family as opposed to the place.
Can you tell me about your parents? You said that your dad was a mechanic.
Yeah, my dad was a mechanic. My gran used to say that my dad was extremely bright and intelligent
and was top of the score or top of his year but I think she wanted him to go on to
do something other than being a mechanic but that was really what he wanted to do.
So my dad was a mechanic. My mum did work in a printing factory before she had all of us
and but then she left work when I think when she got married and then she had all of us.
So my dad did go into the army for two years to do his nationals and my mum had already had my
eldest sister then, Janet and then I think after he came out she had Andrew and then Sandra and then me.
So four of you? Yeah, four of us. There was a fifth but it was still born before me I think.
You mentioned the petrol station in Pwll Merig. There isn't a petrol station
there now is there? There is. The petrol station in the shop is still there but the mechanics part
of it the garage is is not there. So that is that the petrol station just outside Pwll Merig?
Yeah if you're coming from Caldecourt you've got the shop on the left hand side the garden centre
and then it's first right the garage first right and I think now where the garage was
where my dad had the pit that is now where there's like a car cleaning thing to clean your car
and that was where my dad's garage was. Did he continue with that business throughout his career?
He did for a long time. The garage was a jet garage by the way at the time with the yellow
sign. He did for a while but then I remember my younger days we had it just seemed like no
money worries because I had birthday parties and my dad had a nice light blue
jag which I remember yeah I had leather seats and some sort of cassette thing wasn't like
cassettes as we know it it was like an older thing with like solid cassette thing and all it was
and he used to play music on it when he used to take us to school but I remember those
those days fondly we used to have birthday parties and lots of presents and things and then all I
remember was later on perhaps when I was maybe nine ten eleven something like that and the birthday
parties stopped because my dad's garage didn't wasn't doing as well I remember my mum and dad
saying it was because people were made redundant from lambworn steelworks and it affected my dad's
business so my dad was out of work for a little while but then he worked for Red and White in
Chester yeah and he started at the bottom and he worked his way up and he became union leader
union rep I think.
How did you spend your evenings when you were growing up?
My younger days very much out on the green playing with my friends and we used to do
like I said I hide and seek and skipping and tag quite a lot of tag
and I remember we used to make mud pies and I think we got quite dirty
and then in my teens I used to spend a lot of time with my friends I can't really remember until
about 15 16 or maybe a bit older 16 17 when we used to go to the pub and they used to play a lot
of pool in my late teens.
So did you go to school in Cardacol? Yes went to West End School first infant school
which is down the bottom of the road and my earliest memories were
when I was younger starting school and playing in a Wendy house with Susan Burroughs
who is a black girl with beautiful long long hair and she took me into the Wendy house because I
was apparently unconsolable my mum told me that she could hear me all the way up the street
she was walking away I didn't want to go to school so that was West End School the only thing really
I remember about it apart from that was Mrs Miranda's who is still living and living in
Rockets I believe and my dad used to drive us in the Jag a group of children from the street
and we had to shut our eyes and tell dad where we were between here and West End
which really wasn't very far and he used to play Valdunigan
on these big cassette tape things in the car I remember that and that's about as much as I
remember from West End Infants and then I went to Church Road School
and my mum used to give me a little few pence for the bus to come home but I never caught the
bus on the way home I walked and I spent the money on a Tempe mix-up sweets. So the two schools
particularly one is infants and one is juniors West End is infants and Church Road is juniors
it's still the case today yes only they've got different well West End is no longer because
it's been knocked down recently the school there's houses there now and Church Road is now called
something else and the other thing I remember from Church Road is my mum used to come because I was
very very close to my mum so in West End she used to I think on the way perhaps to the shops or
something she used to walk up the lane which was adjacent to the fence by the playground
and she used to give me little kisses in between the fence in playtime or lunchtime
so used to do that quite regularly and in Church Road Junior School I remember her
coming to meet me on a Friday because I always wanted her to meet me every day but she wouldn't
so she used to come up and meet me on a Friday and we used to go down to the village and she
used to get me a magazine called Twinkle this is a little girl's magazine at that time
and she used to get me some sweets and but I remember when I was very little
walking through the village with my mum and she used to stop and say hello to people and they
used to talk about the weather and I just remember distinctly remember tugging on her hand thinking
it's so boring when she stops and talks to people about the weather but she seemed to know everybody
in Caldecott which was very annoying because I didn't like her talking to other people
so that was that. So for the listener can you explain
what Caldecott is now you refer to as a village yeah so a change from being a village to a town?
It's completely different now yeah it's so very completely different
for example when I was in my teens and we used to go up the pub usually the Measure, the Cross,

those three pubs were the the centre of everybody's every teenage person's life in

when did you leave school and what did you do after that? I left school when I was 17
I did my O levels and then I went to Nash College which is now Colleague Gwent
